Adding a proof of concept for the v2 component model.

This POC is not meant for merging as-is, but rather as a preview for
early review. It implements the checkbox component only, and only
addresses the JS side of things (please disregard CSS changes,
as they're the minimum set of changes to enable a simple demo).

Currently only Closure compiler transpilation ('gulp closure') works.

Main changes:
- Moved component code to ES2015.
  Using classes, getters/setters, string interpolation and fat arrow
  syntax where appropriate.
- Removed dependency on componentHandler.
  Components are self-sufficient, with basic automatic initialisation
  on load.
- Components do not modify their own DOM structure.
  Adding and removing classes and changing properties is OK, creating
  and removing DOM elements is not.
- Removed IIFEs around component JS, as well as uniffe and deps.
  Individual components don't need to be inside IIFEs. These should
  be applied through our pipeline.
- Removed manual exporting of symbols.
  Relying on globals is not the best of practices, and this made for
  very awkward-looking code. We now use the @export syntax to let
  Closure compiler know that it should export a symbol, together
  with a utility script ('utils/export.js') that performs the actual
  exporting without relying on a hardcoded 'window' global.

Switching to ESLint from JSHint + JSCS.

ESLint is a single, actively-maintained linter, which is easy to
configure and has good presets. Switching to it allowed me to
identify and correct a number of existing code quality issues.

A lot of the work in this PR will probably be overriden by the move
to the v2 component model later, but it's best to do things one
step at a time :)

Some highlights:
- Splits 'lint' task in two: one for sources, one for aux files.
- Sets two types of linting failures: errors and warnings.
  The tasks only fail for errors.
- Adjusts line lengths all over the place (sticking to 80 char).
- Doesn't switch any of the source to ES6, since we don't have the
  plumbing in place for that yet.

chore: Create v2 release infrastructure (#4883)

* Remove version from top-level package.json as it is private and makes
  no sense.
* Update lerna to 2.0.0-beta.30
* Normalize all built css files to look like built js files
* Create pre-release scripts (described below)
* Add package-level dist/ folders to .eslintignore
* Add npm script to generate changelog using standard-version
* Add post-release script to generate changelog based off of
  packages/material-design-lite version
* Update CONTRIBUTING.md with releasing info

Pre-release Scripts
-------------------

* `scripts/lib/get-updated-pkgs.js` exports a utility function that uses
  lerna to retrieve all packages that have been updated since the last
  release. It does this by monkey-patching some lerna modules to
  suppress its output, and then uses its UpdatedPackagesCollector to
  gather updates.
* `scripts/determine-pkg-versions.js` analyzes all commits from the
  prior release to HEAD. It then uses these commits to determine the
  appropriate version updates for all MDL components needing an update,
  as well as the overall material-design-lite package version. It then
  prints this informatino to the console, as well as writes it to a log
  file in the repo root. This output should be used in conjunction with
  `lerna publish` to correctly update the versions of all packages
  which need it. Note that project-wide breaking changes will probably
  still have to manually be updated using lerna's `--repo-version` flag
  or similar, so this script functions more as a helper.
* `scripts/pre-release` runs tests to ensure no breakages, builds MDL,
  copies the built assets over into each component's `dist/` dir, and
  then runs `scripts/cp-pkgs.js` followed by
  `scripts/determine-pkg-versions.js`.

Known Issues
------------

Lerna currently hard-codes commit messages when it bumps all package
versions, and these commit messages are incompatible with what
`validate-commit-msg` expects. We're tracking the issue at
https://github.com/lerna/lerna/issues/395 and if we need to release
before a fix is in, we could either unlike `validate-commit-msg` for the
initial publish, or write a `prepare-commit-msg` script to modify
lerna's commit to conform to our conventions.

refactor: Move tests from tape to mocha (#296)

Implements all of #5 except for cross-browser testing.

This commit migrates all of our testing infrastructure from tape over to
mocha. We were hitting tape's limits in terms of usability for MDC-Web,
and this gives us a clean break.

Note that most of the changes here were done using an automated script
that can be found at
https://gist.github.com/traviskaufman/59476a12b65925d06b048b61b8ef085c

Note that there are some bugs in the code but I double-checked and it
looked like everything transpiled correctly.

 ## Improvements over the old infrastructure

- _Massive_ speedup in test runtime. Our full suite executes in ~6s
  (locally), which is about 3x faster than before.
- No pollution from TAP console output, only the results from the karma
  reporter are logged to the command line.
- A way better debugging experience. You can now exclude one or more
  tests, or include one or more tests, a big step up from test.only()
  that existed before. Furthermore, the Karma Debug UI now uses mocha's
  html reporter, which produces beautiful output and allows you to drill
  down into individual tests and only run them, view the test code in
  the browser, and more.
- All of the ease and usability of mocha (returning promises for async
  tests, a rich set of configuration options, top-level exception
  handling within tests, etc.)
- A more robust assertion library using chai, including better error
  reporting when assertions fail.

 ## What Changes

 ### Spec Descriptions

Instead of

```js
// math.test.js

import test from 'tape';

test('1 + 1 equals 2', (t) => {
  t.equal(1 + 1, 2);
  t.end();
});
```

You write

```js
// math.test.js

import {assert} from 'chai';

suite('MDCMath');

test('1 + 1 equals 2', () => {
  assert.equal(1 + 1, 2);
});
```

There is one `suite()` function per file, which is a top-level
description of the tests this file contains. Suites should always start
with `MDC`, which is enforced by eslint.

 ### Testdouble verifications

Instead of writing

```js
t.doesNotThrow(() => td.verify(mockAdapter.addClass('foo')));
```

You write

```js
td.verify(mockAdapter.addClass('foo');
```

 ### tape assertion methods vs. chai's assertion methods

- `t.true` -> `assert.isOk`
- `t.false` -> `assert.isNotOk`
- everything other assertion method pretty much stays the same. Plus, we
  have even more robust methods to work with thanks to chai.

 ## Next steps

- Re-enabling SauceLabs cross-browser testing, which is the final part
  of #5.

style: Fix linter errors in package subdirectories (#2442)

Our linter commands are missing double quotes around the glob pattern. As a result, we're currently not linting _any_ files in subdirectories of our packages.

E.g.:

* `packages/mdc-chips/chip/mdc-chip.scss` does _not_ get linted
* `packages/mdc-chips/mdc-chips.scss` _does_ get linted

From the [stylelint CLI docs](https://github.com/stylelint/stylelint/blob/a9aad2945976db4bee16805b2df3ed2a44c5debd/docs/user-guide/cli.md#examples):

> When you run commands similar to the examples below, be sure to include the quotation marks around file globs. This ensures that you can use the powers of node-glob (like the `**` globstar) regardless of your shell.

In short, [shells don't support the `**` syntax](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glob_(programming)), so we need to wrap the pattern in double quotes to prevent the shell from trying to parse it.

This ensures that the pattern gets passed verbatim to stylelint, which then passes it to node-glob for parsing (and node-glob _does_ support the `**` syntax).

feat(infrastructure): Auto-crop screenshots & add checkerboard pattern (#2669)

### How to test

```bash
export CBT_USERNAME='...'
export CBT_AUTHKEY='...'
export MDC_GCLOUD_SERVICE_ACCOUNT_KEY_FILE_PATH='...'

npm run screenshot:build
npm run screenshot:test
```

### What it does

1. Automatically crops screenshot images based on their background color
2. Adds a `10px` grid line background pattern to each cell to test color transparency and detect movement

### Why?

Without this PR, if a browser's viewport size changes (e.g., because the URL bar gets taller), all of our screenshot tests would start failing because the image dimensions would be different.

The 1px black border around the page content is to avoid any potential issues with Jimp's auto-cropping detection, and to make it easier to spot changes to a component's `margin`.

### How to test

```bash
npm run screenshot:test
npm run screenshot:test -- --url=classes/mini --browser=chrome
npm run screenshot:approve -- --all --report=https://.../report.json
```

### What it does

* Decreases test time from **~10 minutes** to **~3 minutes**
* Removes the [CBT Screenshot API][screenshot-api] and replaces it with [CBT's Selenium API][selenium-api]:
    - Spins up a single browser VM and captures every URL within that session
    - No interactivity testing yet, but it should be pretty easy to add
* Reduces flakiness significantly:
    - Uses `WebDriver.takeScreenshot()` instead of CBT's OS-level screenshot API
    - Waits for web fonts to load before capturing screenshots (`Roboto` and `Material Icons`)
* Runs up to 3 browsers in parallel, allowing 2 other developers to run their tests concurrently
    - If other people are already running tests, it will only run 1 browser in parallel to avoid consuming all our CBT resources
* `--diff-base` now defaults to the local git repo's `golden.json` file instead of `origin/master`
    - This gives you incremental diffs by default, which are quicker and easier to review
* Ground-up rewrite of almost all code in `test/screenshot/`:
    - Copies all screenshot images and report files to a unique but predictable temp directory. If uploading to GCS fails for some reason, you can still view the images in the temp dir.
    - Adds [Protocol Buffer](https://developers.google.com/protocol-buffers/) (aka "protobuf" or "proto") files for all data structures:
        * Enables IDE autocompletion and real-time type checking
        * Avoids Anonymous Object Hell by providing clear type definitions for every object
    - Reformats all test pages so that they fit inside a mobile viewport without scrolling
    - Uses [Handlebars](https://handlebarsjs.com/) for report page templating
* Keeps existing workflow. E.g.:
    ```bash
    $ npm run screenshot:test
    https://storage.../report.html
    # ... view `report.html` in browser ...
    # ... click "Approve" button ...
    # ... copy/paste CLI command from report page into terminal ...
    $ npm run screenshot:approve -- --all --report=https://storage.../report.json
    ```
* Keeps existing auto-cropping functionality

chore(infrastructure): Increase IE/Edge flake tolerance (#3333) ### What it does - Adds config options in `diffing.json` to fine-tune flaky screenshot test behavior: - Knobs: - Number of retry attempts - Delay before retrying - Font loading timeout - Global settings for all browsers and URLs: - `2` retries - `50ms` font load delay: Gives the browser time to re-render page content w/ new fonts - `500ms` page load delay when retrying: Allows janky rendering to settle - IE/Edge-specific settings for all URLs: - `4` retries: Microsoft browsers flake more often than Chrome/Firefox/Safari - `300ms` font load delay: Gives IE/Edge extra time to re-render page content w/ new fonts - IE/Edge-specific settings for `mdc-textfield` and `mdc-typography` URLs: - `6` retries: I've seen them fail up to 5 times before finally passing - `500ms` font load delay: Gives `MDCTextField` jank time to settle
- Adds a `FlakeConfig` field to every `Screenshot` so that specific browsers/URLs can have different timeouts and tolerances - Adds optional URL query params to all test pages: - E.g.: `focused.html?font_face_observer_timeout_ms=3000&fonts_loaded_reflow_delay_ms=100` - Values come from `Screenshot.flake_config`. If no values are passed, sensible defaults for local development are used. - Adds npm dependency: [`url-search-params-polyfill`](https://www.npmjs.com/package/url-search-params-polyfill) (polyfill for [`URLSearchParams`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/URLSearchParams))
- Stops uploading empty (0px) diff images to GCS - Improves Selenium session termination: - During session startup, if one VM fails by throwing an error, we now wait for all other browsers to finish starting up so that they can be terminated "normally" by calling `driver.quit()`. Previously, any VMs that hadn't finished starting when another VM threw an error would become zombie sessions. There were only two ways to clean them up: A) manually kill them in the CBT UI; or B) wait 2 minutes and rerun the tests (sessions with no activity for at least 2 minutes are automatically killed on startup). - `SIGINT` (Ctrl+C) and `SIGTERM` (`kill`) handlers wait for all sessions to finish starting before killing them, for the same reasons described in the previous bullet. This makes the session termination much more robust. - Changes `process.exit(code)` to `process.exitCode = code` in `run.js`. The former causes Node to exit immediately without waiting for CBT Selenium cancellation requests to complete, whereas the latter causes Node to wait for all timers and unresolved Promises before exiting.
- Changes `Metadata` table headings: - `Author Name` → `Host User` - `Author OS` → `Host OS` ### Example output #### Flaky MS Edge `text-field` page passes after `attempt 5 of 6`: ![screenshot](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/409245/43988127-b3aea150-9ce3-11e8-8094-d43e6619b4b7.png)

The main BREAKING CHANGES:

  • css modules are disabled by default, you need setup their use modules option. You can setup their using local (true is alias for this value) and global (previous behaviour) value.
